title: R41249
content: Prior to 1996, health insurance coverage for mental illness was historically less generous than for physical illnesses, with lower limits, fewer covered services, and higher cost sharing. Mental health parity laws were enacted to address this disparity in insurance coverage. Mental health parity laws aim to equalize insurance coverage for mental health services with medical and surgical services. Policymakers have developed approaches based on coverage mandates and parity requirements to achieve this goal. Mental health parity laws may require insurers to cover certain mental illnesses with mandated coverage and parity requirements. Different policy approaches include full parity, minimum mandated benefit, and mandated offering parity. The federal mental health parity law prior to the ACA employed a mandated offering parity approach. The ACA expands federal mental health parity requirements by mandating coverage of certain mental health and substance abuse disorder services in specific financing arrangements. It does not include a comprehensive coverage mandate for mental health services at the federal level, but contains provisions that mandate coverage. The ACA does not have an explicit coverage mandate for mental health services at the federal level but includes provisions mandating coverage for certain plans. It expands federal mental health parity requirements by applying them to specific financing arrangements, building on existing laws like MHPA and MHPAEA. The MHPA and MHPAEA laws require parity in mental health coverage, including treatment limitations and financial requirements.
